comments.author: FredGandt
comments.text:
*Google TechTalk about JavaScript's Good Parts by Doug Crockford*
I break with *tradition* and love JavaScript :-)
This talk isn't new so some of the *things to come* already came.
Interestingly Doug expresses a dissatisfaction with HTML5 since he sees it 
as being bigger rather than better (regarding issues with the DOM), but 
HTML5 provides <canvas></canvas> which (judging by my initial forays) seems 
to offer an utterly simplified *DOM* that can be utilized to replace the 
cumbersome mess we're used to.
I've used Doug's jslint.com to evaluate my work before, and it has *"...hurt 
my feelings..."*, but since watching this I'm going to *"...man up..."* and 
concentrate harder on learning JavaScript's Good Parts!﻿

bookmark saved to your device that you run only when connected to a network.

this [0, 1, null, 3] instead of what I assume it should look like, [0, 1, 3]

You should always use multiline comment structure. The reason is that if 
you ever post your code of internet forum asking for help, the forum

your comment and code. Multi-line comment will not break by extra new lines 
from formatting.﻿

comments.author: BenRangel
comments.text:
You'll learn more from 20 minutes of this video than reading a tutorial for 
a couple of hours. You understand the language's core better - but not sure 
that you will learn to LOVE it.
Feels like many arguments for the awesomeness of js boils down to ways to 
compensate for missing concepts.
For instance at 25:30 there's a great explanation of being able to add 
properties at run time. But it just boils down to "you can build concepts 
which are not necessarily given to you in javascript". So that's not a 
reason to love JS, it just makes you feel like it's a shame those concepts 
are missing from the start﻿

comments.author: janburse
comments.text:
Well right, we didn't really show objects in our previous post. What 
happened to the "this" keyword? What was this lousy area/2 message, where 
one needed to provide the radius? Let's show how to bring about real 
objects that have a reference to them selves. We will make use of the fix 
point operator. Lets repeat the definition:

fix(F, N) :- call(F, call(fix, F), N).

This means when sending a message to an object we cannot do it via call/2 
anymore. But we have to use fix/2. And the object itself needs an 
additional abstraction so that the fixpoint operator can do his work. Lets 
first check whether our attribute message still works:

?- Obj=This^radius(X)^(X is 1.5), 
fix(Obj,radius(H)).
H = 1.5

Okay, we will use a modified area closure. Instead of the radius as a 
parameter, it will fetch the radius from This. Interestingly when 
internally sending a message, we can still do it with call/2:

?- Obj=This^(radius(X)^(X is 1.5); 
area(Y)^X^(call(This,radius(X)), Y is X*X*pi)), 
fix(Obj,area(J)).
J = 7.0685834705770345

Multiple invokations of This should work in the same vain as our natural 
number check and factorial function were working with the fixpoint operator:

?- Obj=This^(radius(X)^(X is 1.5); 
area(Y)^X^(call(This,radius(X)), Y is X*X*pi); 
show^X^Y^(call(This,radius(X)), 
write('Radius: '), write(X), nl, call(This,area(Y)), 
write('Area: '), write(Y), nl)), 
fix(Obj,show).
Radius: 1.5
Area: 7.0685834705770345

Difference to JavaScript so far: The Closure is immutable. But didn't check 
the dynamic vs. static scoping issue yet.

Previous Post on Record Closures
https://plus.google.com/u/0/b/103259555581227445618/103259555581227445618/posts/i7PK9s6QFfB
﻿

comments.author: ctaylorrrr
comments.text:
Excuse my massive geekiness, but here's a pretty neat video on Javascript. 
I've only gone through a bit, but already, I learned that the language 
isn't imperative by design: Functions are actually closures that pull along 
with them the context within which they're instantiated (not called, not 
defined, but instantiated). This point alone explains *a lot*.

Oh, and also, besides a bit of magic, Javascript is part of the *everything's 
an object club*. I still think it used a fake ID to get in, but whatever :-)
All in all good video. Definitely worth at least a 
listen-in-the-background.﻿

comments.text:
@TheLampCoder Lets say you're writing a fully-features calculator app. 
You'll want to make separate functions for the basic operations (+, -, *, 
/, so on) but might not want to immediately display the result - instead 
you choose to store it until the user wants it displayed. In this case, you 
can write "function add(first, second) { return first + second;" and in 
your main code write something like this: "var result = add(10, 20);" which 
will add the numbers and store then in "result"

What's good with this is that you can make different filters with the 
tooeasy function before it's shown with document.write, if you take a lot 
of different things in document.write by default, there's no way to change 
the content, as it's not a variable, nor function. So you'll anyways need a 
function etc to do this "filtering". And at the end, it will display what 
you've made it show. Let's say a "bad word filter", which removes bad 
words, or adds an hyperlink to links. PHP is easier though :P

@FHomeBrew If you just have "return c;", then everything after that 
semicolon is known as "unreachable code". IE: It will never been executed, 
although I don't think it raises any objection to it. You can however have 
the following: if (condition) { return a+b; } else { return a*b; } This 
example contains no unreachable code. Hope this helps :)

comments.author: goTvQkaA2SUSIZ7-RlmGIg
comments.text:
I think I know why this happens now. This has something to do with "local" 
and "global" variables. The variables that you define within a function can 
only be used by the function itself - no one else may use them. This is 
called a "local" variable. The variables that you define from outside a 
function can be used outside AND inside the function - these are "global". 
It's because "c" is a local variable and we tried to make a global call of 
"c", which obviously makes no sense in JS. :)

comments.author: calvertsarchives
comments.text:
Hi, what I don't understand about any tutorial video about source code, is 
how any of this information, i.e. arrays, lists, whatever, is usable to a 
website for a stranger visiting that site. None of these videos make any 
sense at all to me. It's like, ok, we have just written all this code and 
for what? We have to have a server on our computer and we go to a blank 
page and refresh it and see one or two words that we could've just typed 
onto the page to begin with. Nobody ever explains how any of this code is 
useful or how it all works together to make something happen on a webpage 
that actually matters. Don't get me wrong, I understand you make easy to 
follow videos, and they are better than most I've seen as far as 
explaining, but nobody ever actually uses any of these codes in real world 
explanations as far as how it is used in building a website and further 
more, a particular type of website specifically. And that is really the 
most important challenge for a beginner. If a person could first create a 
tutorial explaining the various source codes and their functions with real 
world examples, i.e. popular websites who use these particular codes, how 
they use them and why and even better still, how they tweak them for their 
own personal usefulness, well now, than we'd have ourselves a good tutorial 
video. After we know these things, as beginners, then we can determine 
which code sources we need and which tutorials to watch, we wouldn't waste 
enormous amounts of time on tutorials we don't even need, we'd also have a 
direction in our studies, a road map, and we'd also understand to a much 
more full respect what you are talking about on your tutorials and why it 
matters. But it is almost impossible to concentrate and wade through 
countless hours of inconsistent videos of people trying to explain what 
appears to be abstract information in generic ways we can't relate to or 
envision. So if you really want to make a good starting point for every 
beginner out there, than please work hard at making this video type I 
mentioned, and you'd be everybody's hero, you'd be original, you'd be the 
ONLY one making these type's of videos and we'd all watch your other videos 
in a much more fuller understanding too. Otherwise you might as well call 
all of your videos advanced levels, not beginning, and also, they are 
pretty much exactly the same as everyone else's videos too. You won't ever 
really stand out from the crowd. I hope this message finds you well, 
sincerely, -a man trying hard as hell to learn.﻿

Might be worth talking about stack overload. when I first started using 
functions I decided to write an entire application bouncing from function 
to function and before I knew it.. crash. Every function must reach its 
"end". Meaning that it needs to either hit a return or the closing curly 
brace before being called again. Otherwise it never unloads from memory and 
keeps adding to the 'stack' and eventually overloading. causing a crash.

litmus test for a "good" presentation, it's really your loss.
